data.title: French Inflation Rebounds In February But Remains Contained
data.description:
By Charlotte de Montpellier, Senior Economist, France and Switzerland

Inflation rises, but solely due to energy

As expected, French inflation increased in February, reaching 1.0% (1.1% for the harmonised index), up from 0.3% in January (0.4% harmonised). Although the figures are slightly higher than the consensus forecast, this rise was expected on our side: it is mainly explained by less favourable base effects. In February 2025, regulated gas tariffs had been cut by 15% following a government decision. That decrease has now dropped out of the price index calculation, as regulated gas tariffs have since remained stable. This mechanically contributes to the rise in the inflation rate. In addition, energy prices on global markets have edged up slightly. Overall, energy inflation is now down only 3% year-on-year, compared with a 7.6% fall in January.

Beyond these energy-related base effects, inflationary pressures remain moderate. Services inflation is still contained at 1.8% year-on-year, following 1.7% in January, whereas Insee was still expecting a rate close to 2% for February in its December forecast. This moderation in services prices helps to limit the overall increase in inflation. Prices of manufactured goods are falling year-on-year (-0.3%), but the decline is less pronounced than in January (-1.2%), notably due to a different timing of the sales period.

In the coming months, a further small rise in headline inflation is likely, as energy base effects gradually become less favourable. Energy inflation should therefore move back into positive territory. This does not, however, signal a marked resurgence in inflationary pressures. On the contrary, inflation in France should remain subdued in the months ahead and fluctuate within a range of 1% to 1.5%. France should therefore continue to be among the countries with the lowest inflation rates in the euro area.

The labour market lacks momentum

In addition, Insee today published employment data for the fourth quarter of 2025, showing a slight decline in salaried employment (-0.1% quarter on quarter, i.e., 40,100 jobs lost), following stability in the third quarter. Salaried employment is now down 0.2% year-on-year (-45,900 jobs), while remaining well above its pre-pandemic level (+4.9%, or +1.3 million jobs). Data on self-employment, which is generally more dynamic, has not yet been published.

Overall, the French labour market therefore remains relatively resilient, with limited job losses. Nevertheless, the lack of momentum is evident, and the likelihood of a turnaround with strongly positive net job creation remains low in the coming months. The employment climate, as measured by the Insee survey, deteriorated further in February, with business leaders showing increased caution regarding hiring. It is therefore likely that France will continue to record slight job losses in the coming months, even though we do not expect a collapse in the labour market.

Overall, economic growth should remain positive but moderate in the absence of a genuine short-term growth driver. We are forecasting GDP growth of 1.0% in 2026, after 0.9% in 2025.

Content Disclaimer

This publication has been prepared by ING solely for information purposes irrespective of a particular user's means, financial situation or investment objectives. The information does not constitute investment recommendation, and nor is it investment, legal or tax advice or an offer or solicitation to purchase or sell any financial instrument. Read more

Original Post

data.title: Northern High Yield Fixed Income Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
For most of the final quarter of 2025, the macroeconomic landscape was shaped as much by what investors couldn’t see as by what they could. The U.S. government shutdown—lasting a record 43 days—created a significant information vacuum just as markets sought clarity on growth, inflation, and policy trajectories. Despite the data fog, the global macro backdrop proved “good enough” for risk assets. Global growth held firm, inflation stayed sticky but avoided more disruptive outcomes, and most central banks leaned more accommodative than hawkish. In the U.S., elevated downside labor market risk kept U.S. Federal Reserve (“Fed”) easing in play, leading to rate cuts even as the economy expanded. However, policymaker dissents emerged as the Fed Funds rate approached the Federal Open Market Committee’s neutral estimate. International markets—particularly Japan and parts of Europe—offered broadly supportive signals, though political uncertainty occasionally weighed on European sentiment. Since mid-2024, most major developed market central banks have cut rates by 150-200 basis points (1.50%-2.00%) or more, meaning some could be close to the end of their easing cycle. The Bank of Japan remains on a separate trajectory with a gradual pace of rate hikes from a highly accommodative starting point, including two in 2025 and two more expected in 2026. Overall, the global tariff environment proved less disruptive than earlier fears. U.S. monthly tariff collections rose but remained well below levels implied by announced policies, while statutory rates edged lower as deals and exemptions took hold. Still, investors monitored persistent trade-related risks alongside other potential headwinds, including slower AI investment, labor market softening, bond market volatility tied to inflation or fiscal stress, and ongoing risk of geopolitical shocks.

Financial markets capped a strong 2025 with 4Q gains across both equities and fixed income. Many fixed income segments gained around 1%. The Treasury yield curve steepened as short-end rates dropped following multiple rate cuts in the quarter by the U.S. Federal Reserve. Credit spreads were mostly unchanged in both investment grade and high yield, ending near their lowest levels in 2025. Global equities added a little more than 3% as non-U.S. regions outperformed the U.S. in U.S. dollar terms (despite slight U.S. dollar strengthening). U.S. equity returns were positive (roughly 2.5%).

The U.S. Federal Reserve continued easing, delivering 25-basis point (0.25%) cuts at each of its two meetings. However, an increase in hawkish dissents and adjustments to the policy statement signaled a higher threshold for future reductions. Even so, ongoing easing contributed to further steepening of the Treasury curve, as front-end yields through five years moved lower. The 2‑ year yield ended the quarter at 3.47%, down 14 basis points (0.14%). In contrast, longer-term rates remained more resilient, with the 10-year yield up 2 basis points (0.02%) to 4.17%.

Investment grade (IG) credit spreads widened by 3 basis points (0.03%) to 0.73%, while high-yield (HY) spreads tightened by 1 basis point (0.01%) to 2.66%. In terms of return, IG fixed income gained 1.1%, with high yield slightly outperforming at 1.3%. Periods of short-lived weakness followed by a strong recovery mirrored the pattern seen throughout most of the year. As a result, credit spreads enter 2026 below where they began 2025 across many quality buckets. Fundamentals continue to look healthy, but AI-related capex is helping to accelerate corporate debt issuance.

Explanation of Results

High Yield Fixed Income had positive performance October through December, adding to an already positive year. The broad High Yield index returned 131 basis points (1.31%) for the quarter, ending the year up 8.62% as measured by the Bloomberg US Corporate High Yield Issuer Capped 2% Index. Healthcare and Finance Companies led sector performance over the final quarter of 2025. Healthcare benefitted from positive earnings and sector rotation as the market sought quality while interest rate cuts from the U.S. Federal Reserve and steepening of the yield curve helped Finance Companies. Packaging and Railroads lagged sector performance over the quarter. Packaging underperformed on concerns about some of the more highly leveraged issuers addressing upcoming maturities while softening freight volumes and high fixed costs negatively affected Railroads.

High Yield recorded positive inflows October through December with $3.8 billion entering the asset class (Source: Lipper). The primary market issued $65 billion over the quarter, capping a very busy year as $331 billion was issued throughout 2025, the busiest year since 2021 ($469 billion) (Source: Barclays). Companies have taken advantage of market strength to proactively address funding needs. We view this as a positive to underlying fundamentals for our market.

The fund outperformed its benchmark. An overweight to CCC rated bonds helped performance while an underweight to BB rated bonds was a detractor. An overweight to Independent Energy was a positive while overweighting Midstream lessened performance. Security selection within Media & Entertainment and Healthcare was beneficial to performance while security selection within Cable & Satellite and Utilities and Consumer Cyclical Services detracted.

Holdings are subject to change and current and future portfolio holdings are subject to risk.

Performance as of 12/31/2025

1 Bloomberg U.S. Corporate High Yield 2% Issuer Capped Index is an unmanaged index that measures the market of U.S. dollar-denominated, non-investment grade, fixed-rate, taxable corporate bonds. It is a version of the Bloomberg High Yield Corporate Bond Index except it limits its exposure of each issuer to 2% of the total market value and redistributes any excess market value Index-wide on a pro-rata basis. It is not possible to invest directly in an index.*High Yield Index: Bloomberg US Corporate High Yield Total Return Index. The Bloomberg US Corporate High Yield Bond Index measures the USD-denominated, high yield, fixed-rate corporate bond market. Securities are classified as high yield if the middle rating of Moody's, Fitch and S&P is Ba1/BB+/BB+ or below.

Performance quoted represents past performance and does not guarantee future results. Investment return and principal value will fluctuate so that shares, when redeemed, may be worth more or less than their original cost. Current performance may be lower or higher than that shown here. Performance data current to the most recent month end is available by calling 800-595-9111.

The Gross and Net Expense Ratios are as of the most recent prospectus. The Net Expense Ratio includes contractual expense reimbursements that, if not extended, will end on July 31, 2026.

Bond Risk: Bond funds will tend to experience smaller fluctuations in value than stock funds. However, investors in any bond fund should anticipate fluctuations in price, especially for longer-term issues and in environments of rising interest rates.

Defaulted Bond Risk: The risk that the inability or unwillingness of an issuer or guarantor of a fixed-income security to meet its payment or other financial obligations will adversely affect the value of the Fund’s investments and its returns. Changes in the credit rating of a debt security held by the Fund could have a similar effect.

High-Yield Risk: The risk that the Fund’s below-investment grade fixed-income securities, sometimes known as “junk bonds,” will be subject to greater credit risk, price volatility and risk of loss than investment grade securities, which can adversely impact the Fund’s return and NAV. High yield securities are considered highly speculative and are subject to the increased risk of an issuer’s inability to make principal and interest payments.

Municipal Bond Risk: Debt securities issued by state or local governments may be subject to special political, legal, economic and market factors that can have a significant effect on the portfolio's yield or value.

Sector Risk: The risk that companies in similar businesses may be similarly affected by particular economic or market events, which may, in certain circumstances, cause the value of securities of all companies in a particular sector of the market to decrease.

Not FDIC insured | May lose value | No bank guarantee

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Innovative Industrial Properties: Cannabis REIT At Risk Premium (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Innovative Industrial Properties (IIPR) just released Q4 and full-year 2025 earnings. With tenant defaults in 2025 and cannabis rescheduling uncertain, the share price remains depressed, but I think the valuation is finally attractive.

Summary of Previous Thesis

The first time I covered this company was almost two years ago, in May 2024. At the time, IIPR was still a cannabis pure play, by way of its REIT structure. General sentiment about cannabis at that time was positive, but I declined to rate their shares a Buy. I did acknowledge the positives that came with this investment:

  • Listing on a major exchange, rare for any cannabis company
  • First mover as a cannabis REIT
  • Steady profits
  • Low-risk, triple-net leasing model
  • Virtually zero debt

I largely felt that IIPR lacked room for growth, with much of the cannabis market developed at that time. I wrote:

Cannabis continues to be a popular search among stocks for outsized returns on waves of legalization. With IIP, a honeymoon of vertical growth rates seems to be behind it, and there are no obvious catalysts to this company taking off. Rather, it will be a game of managing the current portfolio and working with tenants to improve the properties, while incrementally adding new tenants as more layers of legalization come down and bring more growth into the industry.

It just didn't seem discounted for what seemed likely to be slower growth ahead, hence my Hold rating.

Strategic Adjustment

Cannabis investing depends heavily on politics. Former optimism hinged on the Biden Administration's intentions to reschedule cannabis as a Schedule III substance under the Controlled Substances Act. This would pose enormous tax benefits, improving the cash flow for tenants across IIPR's portfolio.

Biden's exit from the 2024 election and Harris's defeat created much more uncertainty on this, and previous rescheduling efforts halted under Trump. Cyclical factors, such as oversupply and upcoming debt maturities, weakened many operators. IIPR therefore announced a strategic pivot in August 2025. They would be diversifying into life sciences, not longer purely owning and acquiring cannabis properties.

It indicated the limited growth available to cannabis that I worried was present. Management finally seemed to concur and acted accordingly. Unlike their cannabis portfolio, which consists of directly owned assets, the shift into life sciences is done through investment in IQHQ, Inc., a life sciences real estate platform. The two primary investment vehicles entail:

  • Providing a $100M credit facility at 13.5% interest
  • Purchase of $170M of IQHQ's preferred stock at a 15% yield
  • (Thirdly, conditional warrants to buy equity in IQHQ)

Put in simple terms, IIPR is acting as equity REIT in cannabis and mortgage REIT in life sciences with this shift.

Full-Year 2025 Results

The full-year results and latest Form 10K illustrate the issues that hit IIPR's portfolio. The first and most obvious is the impact to the top line.

Annual revenue, which had cleared $300M in 2023 and 2024 fell to $266M in 2025. In their MD&A section, management explained:

The decrease was primarily driven by tenant defaults, resulting in a decrease of $46.9 million related to properties leased to PharmaCann, Gold Flora, TILT, and 4Front.

The cash flow statement, however, shows some subtle changes between 2024's and 2025's results.

Common share distributions remained steady in 2025, in spite of this sharp stress on the portfolio. Moreover, IIPR went from some share issuance in 2024 to some buybacks in 2025. The move into life sciences also allowed them access to a credit facility on a balance sheet that was nearly free of debt before.

The balance sheet shows total assets remaining relatively steady, around $2.3B, with $290M in notes due this year. The $102M credit facility to support the life sciences segment is also apparent. That the reported assets did not grow with the contribution of the credit facility is not, as one might think, primarily a consequence of realized losses or asset impairments. The income statement shows that normal depreciation and amortization accounted for this.

Coming into 2026, IIPR is still primarily a cannabis REIT, but life sciences became 6.6% of its portfolio in less than a year. It is still primarily a REIT and business exposed to the strengths and weakness of cannabis.

Outlook and Valuation

When I wrote about IIPR the first time, it was valued $107 per share, had market cap over $3B, and a dividend yield of about 6.5%. Now, it's $53, has a market cap of $1.4B, and dividend yield of 14.8%. Just on valuation alone, it's a very different prospect, but we still need to assess if it's a good price, taking into account the changed fundamentals and the outlook they support.

First, how sustainable in the $7.60 annual dividend? Let's look at how IIPR breaks down its FFO, normalized FFO, and adjusted FFO.

We see that FFO removes changes related to asset values, NFFO removes one-off cash items, and AFFO removes some other non-cash expenses. AFFO is one of management's preferred measures of financial performance, as it's indicative of the cash flow to support the dividend based on a long-term, recurring state of the business.

No measure of FFO per share in 2025, even AFFO at $7.24, is sufficient to cover the current dividend.

Even just focusing on Q4, which has the full benefits of the move into life sciences, and annualizing it is insufficient. During the earnings call, Executive Chairman Alan Gold gave positive outlook on the dividend but fell short of confirming coverage:

Well, I think, first of all, the dividend -- our dividend policy is set by our Board, and they review what has occurred in the past and the projections going forward. But what we're seeing is this return to growth, and we're seeing strong re-leasing activity, which is driving revenues. And we continue to see -- and we have the resolutions of some of these major lease or major litigations. And with those resolutions and the activity -- the leasing activity we're seeing, we continuously feel positive about where we are with regards to our dividend.

It's very plausible that the dividend could be trimmed a bit (perhaps as low as $7.00) if upcoming quarters have enough non-recurring cash expenses. Even so, that's still about a 13% yield on cost, giving IIPR something of a risk premium.

An example of non-recurring cash items may include refinancing the 2026 notes, which come due this May. In the Form 10K, management stated:

As of December 31, 2025, the outstanding principal balance on our Notes due 2026 was $291.2 million and we plan to refinance these notes prior to maturity in May 2026.

No announcement has been made, but the Form 10K also mentions that these notes were issued in 2021, when interest rates were much lower and when IIPR was given an investment-grade credit rating. The rating is intact, but interest rates are up.

Assuming another five-year issue, the 5Y Note (US5Y) rose from about 0.80% to 3.63%, more recently. As the 2026 notes bear 5.5% interest, it's conceivable they would need to be refinanced at 8%. With a $291M balance, that would be a $7.2M annual difference, plus a few million related to underwriting and repurchasing the old notes. With AFFO already too low at $205M for 2025, this friction doesn't help. The concern isn't in ability to refinance, so much as it is the higher cost of capital going forward.

Overall, I am less worried about the durability of their cannabis portfolio than before. This is because President Trump announced in December, for the first time, that he was committed to rescheduling cannabis to Schedule III. While the long-term pacing of this is still unclear, it bodes well for these assets, whose tenants have been in a cyclical rut.

This improvement, plus the substantially lower valuation (14.8% dividend, 7x AFFO multiple), make IIPR worth upgrading to Buy. Nevertheless, let's keep in mind a major risk factor, besides any implicit to a dividend trim.

Several of their major tenants have significant debt and questionable cash flow to repay it:

  • Ascend Wellness Holdings (AAWH)
  • Curaleaf (CURLF)
  • Cannabit (CBSTF)
  • 4Front (FFNTF) (This is in receivership)
  • Cresco (CRLBF)

These are five that have publicly available financial data and account for 36.1% of the portfolio's ABR. If they all become distressed, then IIPR would have to worry about more than a trimmed dividend. Depending on how soon Trump reschedules cannabis, many of these companies could end up in a similar spot as 4Front, leading to defaults and lack of payments.

IIPR can find new tenants among better-capitalized operators in the industry, but this would take time, possibly eliminating the dividend in the meantime.

Conclusion

The risk to IIPR's cannabis properties still loom and have, in part, materialized. The high-yield investments in life sciences, unexpected tailwinds from rescheduling under Trump, and heavily reduced valuation, however, make the shares more attractive than before. With the dividend now more properly representing a risk premium, I upgrade IIPR to Buy.

data.title: German Labour Market Sends Mixed Messages In February
data.description:
By Carsten Brzeski, Global Head of Macro

German unemployment dropped by 14,700 in February, the best February performance of the labour market since 2022. At the same time, however, the fact that the absolute number of those unemployed remains above the politically important 3 million is anything but good news. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate remained unchanged at 6.3%.

No turning point in sight yet

Over the last four years, German unemployment has increased by some 500,000. This gradual worsening reflects textbook economics; with the economy effectively stagnating for more than five years and industry facing severe structural challenges, a deterioration in the labour market was inevitable. At the same time, employment has started to gradually drop since last summer, providing additional evidence of a structurally changing labour market: a shrinking working force due to demographics, sectoral and geographical shifts due to the industrial transition and higher entrance barriers for graduates due to AI.

Looking ahead, the number of vacancies has come down further and even if employment plans in both manufacturing and services have started to rebound, we see the gradual worsening of the labour market continuing throughout the year. Previous and potential additional announcements of cost-cutting measures across the automotive and other industries as well as the continuing increase in bankruptcies suggest that conditions will first worsen before they improve. The AI disruption of the labour market could add to this. If we are right and the cyclical recovery of the German economy unfolds over the coming months, the labour market, however, should stabilise towards the end of the year.

All in all, today's labour market report sends a mixed message but definitely no signs of a turning point. Instead, the gradual worsening looks set to continue.

Content Disclaimer

This publication has been prepared by ING solely for information purposes irrespective of a particular user's means, financial situation or investment objectives. The information does not constitute investment recommendation, and nor is it investment, legal or tax advice or an offer or solicitation to purchase or sell any financial instrument. Read more

Original Post

data.title: Ashtead: A Great Business But Fairly Valued (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
My last piece on Ashtead (ASHTF) was my June “buy” piece, Ashtead: Lots Still To Look Forward To. Since its publication, the Ashtead share price has moved up 23%. (Since that piece was published, as part of ongoing portfolio reallocation, I have sold my stake in Ashtead).

With its primary listing due to move to New York next month, alongside plans to host an investor day in the city, now seems like an apposite time to provide a snapshot of the company’s health.

The Basic Investment Thesis

In June, and previous pieces, I set out what I see as the investment thesis.

Plant rental is a large market and one that benefits from some attractive economic characteristics. Demand can often be high, contracts can stretch for months or years, specialist requirements can make some customers effectively captives. Ashtead has rolled up lots of smaller businesses over the years and also taken a strategic approach to business building. That has given it economies of scale and attractive profitability.

One ongoing risk, though, is the inherently cyclical nature of plant rental. As the economy weakens and construction activity reduces, rental providers like Ashtead can be left holding the baby in terms of having lots of capital tied up in pricy plant that lies idle.

What sets Ashtead apart from many rivals, in my view, is how strategic it has been about growing the business, through a series of strategic growth plans. In my prior piece, I reckoned that Ashtead was undervalued given its proven business model and North American focus.

Current Financial Year Shows Modest Revenue Growth but Reduced Profitability

In December, the company released its results for the first half of its current financial year. These were fine at the top line, though less impressive at the bottom line.

Revenues rose 1% year-on-year, but a 9% decline in operating profit fed through to a 10% fall in pre-tax profit. Revenue performance was the same across both the first and second quarter, but those profit metrics were both sequentially worse in the second quarter.

The company struck an upbeat note about current demand, saying that it continued to see “positive leading indicators for local non-residential construction activity”. It also launched a new $1.5bn share buyback, which I see as a strong sign of management confidence coming hot on the heels of $714m of buybacks in the first half.

For the full year, the company is guiding for rental revenue growth of 0%-4%, and free cash flow of $2.2bn-$2.5bn. That compares favourably to last year’s free cash inflow of $1.8bn.

Can Ashtead Step Up a Gear?

Over the long run, Ashtead has performed phenomenally well. It is up 6,410% since the start of 2010, for example.

But the current outlook feels more like “steady as she goes” rather than transformative to the investment case. Meanwhile, an uncertain outlook for the U.S. economy and therefore for the construction market in general (and the plant rental market within it specifically) poses a risk to revenues and profits over the coming years.

I have outlined in previous pieces on the name that the company’s strategic plans have helped it perform very well in the past and I expect the same of its current plan (Sunbelt 4.0). Indeed, in its interim results the company specifically noted, “As we execute on Sunbelt 4.0, we expect a number of years of strong earnings and free cash flow generation”. Ashtead’s free cash flow generation is substantial and I do think it has the potential to keep that flowing if the construction market holds up. As it points out, having invested heavily in infrastructure under its previous strategic plan, it is now trying to make the most of that infrastructure to generate revenues and, thereby, cash flow.

But while I like the business, see it as very well run and also appreciate the financial potential of Sunbelt 4.0, I do not see transformational growth drivers in the coming year or two. The fact that the year’s outlook for rental revenue has at its bottom end a flat year-on-year performance underlines that point I feel.

Valuation Does Not Now Look Compelling

Currently Ashtead’s price-to-earnings ratio is 22, which is a bit steeper than I would like to find it attractive.

At the interim point, net debt was $10.5bn. The current market cap is $29.7bn, making for an enterprise value of $40.2bn. Last year’s cash flow from operating activities was $2.2bn. I expect this year’s may be higher given the company’s guidance on cash flow overall, but using last year’s number, the current enterprise value is around 18 times operating cash flow. Again, I do not find that especially attractive but I do at least think it is justifiable for a proven company with ongoing growth potential.

I expect the switch to a primary listing in New York City to give the share price some benefit as it will help it to access deeper liquidity more easily, in an end market that anyway accounts for most of its business.

Still, as outlined above, I see current share price as reasonable rather than attractive to start a position and accordingly, on valuation grounds, am downgrading my rating from “buy” to “hold”.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Why Gold In 2026? A Cross-Asset Perspective
data.description:
Hedging overconfidence!

Cross-asset returns were surprisingly solid in 2025 and so far this year. Market disruptions caused by US tariffs and other global geopolitical events have proved to be short-lived. And while much of the hype has been on the growing AI theme, returns have been strong across assets and sectors; explained, in part, by a resilient economy (Chart 1 & Chart 2).

Chart 1: Markets on a tear...

Returns of key asset classes in 2025 and y-t-d*

Chart 2: ...thanks, in part, to a resilient economy

GDP consensus forecasts*

Looking ahead, risk assets are sitting at uneasy highs against a backdrop of a world in turmoil (Chart 3 & Chart 4). Yes, there are a host of tailwinds that should support a revival in growth throughout the year, including easier monetary policy and the global fiscal boost. But the consensus narrative of a global economy that has proved “robust” in the face of tariffs and turmoil underestimates the very real risks that remain.

Chart 3: Equities are expensive…

Forward P/E ratios vs. 20-yr history*

Chart 4: … and so are credit markets

Credit spread vs. 20-yr history*

The concerning mismatch between the level of conviction in the outlook vs. the economic policy uncertainty currently on display (Chart 5) is one of the key reasons gold had its best year since the 1970s and continues to do well year-to-date. And while there is perhaps a concern that gold looks overbought and might struggle to find marginal investment buyers, it remains strategically under-owned (Chart 6).

Chart 5: Remarkable certainty about growth as economic policy uncertainty is at extreme highs

US Economic Policy Uncertainty Index and dispersion of forecasts for nominal GDP*

Chart 6: Gold remains strategically under-owned

Gold's investment share of global equities and bonds*

For now, the central problem for investors is working out how to position their portfolios amid the clear disconnect between the level of conviction in the outlook and the policy uncertainty. Yes, investors can and should recognise the monetary and fundamental forces that have driven markets higher – especially with more easing on the way in 2026. But stretched valuations and persistent macro risks demand caution, emphasising the need for diversified portfolios. As geopolitics and shifting US policies continue to impact asset allocation, we believe there should be a focus on quality assets, such as gold.

Bonds, a no-go?

Much of the optimistic growth outlook for this year rests on the expectation that the US fiscal impulse will turn positive. In such a scenario, inflation is the biggest potential spoiler, particularly as US core PCE inflation is already proving sticky at around 3%. The fact that there is very little slack in the US economy clearly adds to this risk. Indeed, the US economy has been running above its potential growth rate for much of the past four years, and the output gap is now near past highs; historically, such scenarios put sustained upward pressure on consumer price inflation (Chart 7).

Chart 7: Inflation worries are justified

US inflation expectations, US core inflation and output gap*

If core inflation rises meaningfully, the Fed will have to raise short-term rates again. In other words, the bond market is not out of the woods, and another cyclical upleg in developed market yields could be in the offing. And while a clear turn towards policy hawkishness could curb gold demand in the near term due to a higher opportunity cost, gold should be supported in the medium term via stronger inflation-hedging demand and a higher stock-bond correlation (Chart 8).

Chart 8: Bonds are not as effective as they used to be

US Treasuries and gold performance during equity drawdowns*

Moreover, gold can still perform its strategic role despite the big rally we have witnessed over the last several years. Historically, meaningful gold returns prior to a market event have not prevented it from behaving like a safe-haven asset during a market stress event (Chart 9).

Chart 9: Gold is always there when called upon... even when returns have been solid in prior years

(a) Annual gold returns prior to and during the GFC*

(b) Annual gold returns prior to and during the 2022 inflation shock bear market*

Sources: Bloomberg, ICE Benchmark Administration, World Gold Council

*Panel (a) based on data from 31 December 2004 to 31 December 2008. Panel (b) based on data from 31 December 2018 to 31 December 2022. Gold returns calculated using LBMA Gold Price PM. US Stocks calculated using S&P 500 Total Return Index.

Equities: a bumpy road ahead…

The likelihood of reaching breaking points in equity markets during 2026 is difficult to ascertain with any level of confidence, but for a hint as to the bumpy road ahead, look no further than the surging US margin debt – a sign that excesses could be building. Margin debt reflects the amount of funds that investors borrow from their brokers to purchase equities. It typically tracks the performance of the S&P 500, which makes intuitive sense since rising stock prices produce confidence about future equity returns and encourage investors to take on more risk (Chart 10).

Chart 10: Building financial speculation

US margin debt and S&P 500 y/y*

And while growth in margin debt does not necessarily signal an impending peak in the stock market, it is an indication of increasing financial speculation and growing risks to market stability. In fact, there have only been three occasions when the y/y growth of margin debt has exceeded the 12-month return of the S&P 500 by a similar or larger magnitude, as it did in December (Chart 11). This recent surge in margin debt reinforces the notion that there is scope for greater equity market volatility in the year ahead.

Chart 11: Excessive increases in margin debt have preceded equity bear markets

US margin debt minus S&P 500 (% y/y) and S&P 500 Index*

And after a long rally, and with valuations approaching dotcom levels, it would only take a couple of missed earnings targets to puncture confidence. This, in turn, could result in an unwinding of investor leverage positions (potentially magnifying the downside risks to stock prices) and lead to greater safe-haven demand, notably gold. In fact, with few exceptions, gold has been especially effective during such periods of systemic risk, generating positive returns and reducing overall portfolio losses (Chart 12).

Chart 12: Gold provides downside protection

Stocks, bonds and gold performance during various crises*

Conclusion

As investors navigate a landscape marked by stretched valuations, persistent macro risks, and rising pockets of financial excess, the need for resilience in portfolios has rarely been more pressing. In this environment, gold’s strategic role remains as relevant as ever. Its historical ability to provide diversification, mitigate drawdowns during periods of market stress, and perform even after strong run-ups reinforces its value as a core, long-term portfolio component.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Joby Aviation: Monumental 2026 Ahead
data.description:
After a badly timed capital raise, Joby Aviation, Inc. (JOBY) is proving that investors need to be very patient. The air taxi company has made monumental plans for 2026, yet the big capital raise to start 2026 has the stock trading closer to the yearly lows. My investment thesis is ultra bullish on the stock now trading at $10 after souring on Joby Aviation up at $17 back in November.

Ignore Earnings

Joby Aviation announced a big Q4'25 revenue beat as follows, but the market should generally ignore the numbers:

The company bought the passenger business of Blade Air Mobility last year and started reporting related revenues for the helicopter service. The current business is non-meaningful to Joby Aviation, as the company will ultimately replace the helicopters with new eVTOLs, expanding the service operations.

The real focus is on these key dynamics driving the company in 2026 and setting up a 2027 manufacturing ramp.

  • First FAA-conforming aircraft for TIA set to fly shortly: All of the aircraft required for Type Inspection Authorization are also now in production
  • First passengers expected in 2026: Joby expects to carry its first passengers in Dubai this year, as well as completing early operations in the U.S. as part of the White House-backed eVTOL Integration Pilot Program
  • Plans to double production capacity in 2027: Joby signed an agreement to acquire a manufacturing facility in the Dayton, Ohio area, spanning more than 700,000 square feet, supporting plans to double production to four aircraft per month in 2027

Joby Aviation should get the eVTOL aircraft certified by the FAA this year and fly passengers in Dubai. After that, the company can ramp up services as fast as responsible with current plans to build 4 aircraft per month. These aircraft generally have a retail value of $5 million for $20 million worth of aircraft produced per month, though the company plans to place these aircraft into service and generate revenues via passenger fares.

Bad Capital Raise

While all the news surrounding Joby Aviation is generally positive, with the company set to officially launch an air taxi service in 2026 and lead the market, the stock is now trading down towards the lows. Back in January, the company for some reason rushed out a secondary offering that crushed the stock, and it hasn't recovered yet.

The company sold 60.8 million shares at $11.35 and issued $600 million in 9.75% convertible senior notes to raise $1.2 billion when the stock was trading at $14.50 the prior week. Joby Aviation had just recently traded above $16 to start January and at highs of $20 back in 2025, so a big offering that far in the hole wasn't well received by the stock market.

Joby Aviation went into the offering with a cash balance of $1.4 billion after completing another offering at $16.85 per share for $514 million in 2025, so shareholders weren't expecting another big capital raise. The company would've appeared to have the capability to sell shares on successful FAA testing and certification this year, questioning the need to rush into a bad deal.

The company now has $2.6 billion in pro forma cash to start 2026. The stock has a fully diluted market cap in the $9.5 billion range, with a forecast for 2026 revenues topping $100 million.

On the Q4'25 earnings call, CFO Rodrigo Brumana confirmed the 2026 revenues are mostly related to Blade as follows:

For 2026, we expect total revenue in the range of $105 million to $150 million with the vast majority generated by Blade. The Blade passenger business has operated seamlessly since closing with consistent service levels and customer demand. 2026 will remain a year of testing, learning and continued integration into Joby's broader commercial strategy.

The big question is where revenues can go in 2027 with aircraft production around 50 next year and operations launched in Dubai and quickly expanded in NYC. Joby Aviation is a future billion plus business with a simple ramp to far higher aircraft production rates in 2028 and beyond.

On FAA certification and air taxi service launch in Dubai, the stock is likely to rally back to the highs of $20. After that, the company will have to scale to the $1+ billion revenue range to warrant a higher price, but Anduril just raised funds at a $60 billion valuation after hitting an estimated $2 billion in sales in 2025. Anduril is an interesting intersection of autonomous defense and aircraft, offering a look into where the valuation of Joby Aviation could hit on a successful ramp of the business over the next few years.

The biggest risk to the story is that lack of FAA certification. Joby Aviation is burning up to $370 million in cash just through the 1H of the year after spending $539 million last year. The company has plenty of cash now, but FAA certification delays in the months and quarters will add up to massive cash burn and loss of investor confidence.

Takeaway

The key investor takeaway is that Joby Aviation has a monumental year ahead. The stock is now appealing after falling 50% from the highs due in part to the company raising substantial cash closer to the lows.

Investors can now buy the stock around $10 with less risk of another capital raise and Joby Aviation much closer to eVTOL certification and air taxi service launch.

data.title: PayPal's Treasury Stock: Hidden Treasure Or Capital Misallocation? (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
PYPL stock: Treasury stock reaches record in FQ4

I last wrote about PayPal Holdings, Inc. (PYPL) on Jan 20 with an article entitled "PayPal: Outlook After Hitting 5-Year Low”. The article was triggered by the large drop in its share prices and also the 10% credit card interest rate cap proposed by the Trump administration and rated the stock as a buy. Since then, the company has released its FQ4, 2025, earnings report (ER) in early Feb. As one of the most popular tickers in the payment space, the ER was quickly reviewed by several other analysts. As such, here I will just provide a very brief recap and then go on to focus on an aspect less mentioned: the latest changes in its treasury stock.

Overall, the company reported another quarter of challenged growth. As shown in the snapshot below, it missed consensus on both lines for FQ4. Topline growth kept accelerating to a rate of 3.7% YOY. Yet in the meantime, the company kept committing substantial resources to repurchase its own shares and build its treasury stock position. In FQ4, its treasury stock has grown to a record of $33.14 billion (for a company with a market capitalization of about $43 billion “only” at its current share prices). Against this backdrop, the central thesis of this follow-up article is that PayPal’s aggressive use of share repurchases has transitioned from a shareholder-friendly activity into a significant capital misallocation.

PYPL stock treasury stock: historical perspective

From past experiences, not many investors really pay attention to treasury stock. Thus, I feel a quick background is in good order. Treasury stock (aka treasury shares, TS) comes from share repurchases. After a company buys back its own shares, it can then either retire these shares or hold the stock for future use, which becomes the treasury shares in this latter case. Many companies buy back their shares, and many choose to not retire the shares bought (for good reasons to be elaborated on in a minute). What made PYPL stand out on my radar is the magnitude and consistency of its TS. As shown in the next chart, PYPL’s TS has been consistently growing in the past decade at rapid rates. As shown in the bottom panel, PayPal's TS grew another 22.3% in FQ4, 2025.

PYPL treasury stock: where it comes from

As just mentioned, TS comes from the shares repurchased but not retired from shareholders. To this end, PYPL has been systematically purchasing its own shares—and again at large scales—in the long term. To wit, the next chart displays the resources PayPal has committed in the past on such repurchases. The top panel shows the absolute dollar amount, and the bottom panel shows the buyback yield (i.e., the size of the repurchases relative to its market cap). As seen, on average, PYPL committed about $798 million per quarter during the past 10 years on these repurchases, which in turn translated into a net common buyback yield of 3.55% on average. The latest buyback in FQ4 is almost 2x higher than the average (about $1.45 billion), and the buyback yield is 13.62%.

PYPL only started a dividend in late 2025 (at $0.14 per share and a FWD yield of around 1.1% as of this writing). If the funds it spent on repurchase were paid out as dividends, it would make PYPL one of the most mouth-watering dividend stocks.

PYPL treasury stock: hidden treasury or capital misallocation

Now, let me get back to a point I mentioned earlier about TS being a sign of shareholder friendliness. Indeed, a large TS position can be a strong sign of a company’s cash flow capability and the share’s attractive valuation ratios. Both of these points can be valid under PYPL’s current conditions. Moreover, when compared to retiring the shares bought back, keeping them in a TS position also offers some potential advantages. The potential advantages can come in various ways, but the common theme in my mind is flexibility. A TS position, especially a sizable one, gives a company flexibility to use these shares opportunistically later.

However, under PYPL’s current conditions, my assessment is that continued capital allocation into TS at these levels constitutes a capital misallocation. Fundamentally, it ignores the diminishing returns of financial engineering in a low-growth environment. Judging by PayPal’s 2026 guidance announced in FQ4, I see large odds for a flat EPS or even a mild decline. I see little odds for the buyback and the continued TS buildup to offset such decline; in turn, I see little odds for the share prices to be supported by the buybacks and/or TS.

If you subscribe to the above notion, then some alternative capital allocation approaches would make immediate sense. To start, to echo a point I made earlier, increasing the cash dividend payouts would return the capital to shareholders so that they can decide what to do themselves. Paying down its debt is a no-brainer in my view also. As seen in the next two charts, PYPL’s total liabilities have remained largely unchanged in recent years (actually increasing slightly from about $55 billion to FQ4’s $60 billion, as shown in the first chart). Furthermore, the borrowing rates on some of its bonds are not low (5%+ as shown in the second chart).

Other risks and final thoughts

Looking into the long term, I think the approach to deal with the challenges is for PayPal to redirect its capital toward aggressive R&D and strategic M&A to bolster its omnichannel presence. The company’s R&D efforts have been in decline in recent years while the industry is evolving rapidly. To wit, the next chart tracks the Research and Development (R&D) to revenue ratio as of TTM for PayPal and Block (XYZ), its closest and most direct competitor in my view. The data spans the last 5 years, from 2017 through FQ4. As seen, PayPal’s R&D intensity has been around 12% of its revenues in 2020~2022. But it has steadily decayed since then to the current level of 9.31%, compared to about 12.38% for Block. And I do see plenty of areas where the company can further its R&D efforts and/or identify acquisition targets. The top areas on my list include AI-driven biometric checkout and rolling out additional Venmo monetization mechanisms/patterns. This approach should yield a higher internal rate of return in the long term than buying back shares of the business in its current state.

In terms of valuation, as aforementioned, the stock is trading at very attractive multiples, either by absolute or relative standards. As shown in the next table, its FWD P/E ratio is in the single digits now (8.87x only) based on the updated 2026 EPS revisions. Again, this points to an almost flat bottom line (with a 0.47% YOY change). EPS recovery is expected to start in FY 2027 with a 4-year CAGR of around 9.5%. Hence, when adjusted for growth projection, PYPL’s PEG (P/E growth) ratio is below 1x, quite GARP-friendly (growth at a reasonable price).

To close, this PYPL revisit was triggered by the updates the company provided in its FQ4 ER with a particular focus on the growth risks and also the record treasury stock buildup. These developments have led me to question its capital allocation. My assessment is that the TS buildup, if continued, represents a capital misallocation that takes resources away from strengthening its underlying operations. These considerations have led me to downgrade my rating to hold.

data.title: Weitz Partners III Opportunity Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
The Partners III Opportunity Fund’s Institutional Class (WPOPX) returned +0.67% in the fourth quarter, compared with +2.39% for the Bloomberg U.S. 3000 Index. For the calendar year, the Fund’s Institutional Class returned +3.17% compared to +17.21% for the index.

A High-Level Portfolio View

We discuss in greater detail the “puts and takes” to our performance for both the quarter and calendar year below, but the punchline is straightforward: our results didn’t measure up in 2025. On the positive side of the ledger, we owned several companies that investors currently deem “AI Winners”, namely Alphabet (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT), Amazon (AMZN) and Meta Platforms (META), that averaged roughly 16% of Fund assets in 2025. Nearly 40% of our holdings represent our view of other long-term, durably growing businesses. These companies range from payment networks (Visa (V), Mastercard (MA)) to insurance-related holdings (Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A)(BRK.B), Aon Corp) and collectively posted returns in excess of 10% in 2025, short of the benchmark return but in most other ways, a respectable year.

On the other hand, our portfolio of life sciences investments (roughly 18% of average assets) experienced a “lost year”. In a different year, we would include these in the high-quality, durable business category. Instead, 2025 began with pressure on research budgets and heightened scrutiny of our national health care apparatus. The industry is reorienting around a “new normal” and a pickup of organic growth in key areas has spurred a rally, ultimately equating to a neutral contribution this year.

Despite hailing from different industries, our top detractors generally have one thing in common: statistically cheap valuations. Averaging roughly 16% of portfolio assets in 2025, what others might call our “deep value” stocks had a disproportionately negative impact on returns. As value-oriented investors, we are comfortable taking contrarian positions, understanding that patience is required for others to see what we do. But we must also be clear-eyed about how our companies’ prospects change and adapt accordingly.

For example, CarMax (KMX) faces a challenging operating environment. Availability and affordability of late model used vehicles (CarMax’s strongest category) remain constrained, while online competitor Carvana has taken share. At the same time, CarMax’s own investments in its omni-channel capabilities have yet to deliver improvements, prompting strategic changes and the CEO’s ousting. While we continue to respect CarMax’s brand and scale advantages, the near-term path to improved fundamentals became less visible, leading us to step aside and monitor developments from the sidelines.

Liberty Broadband’s operating entity, Charter Communications (CHTR), has faced negative headlines, too, but there are important differences. Importantly, connectivity at home and on the go has become a non-discretionary expense for most households, underpinning the durability of Charter’s cash flows in a way that selling used cars does not. Charter’s mobile service continues to win in the market, creating a converged bundled product that competes well for the limited number of customers available. And while Charter still has work to do on its network upgrade program, 2025 is expected to mark the peak year of spending. As this investment moderates, free cash flow should improve, supporting continued share repurchases at today’s depressed prices. With the benefit of hindsight, the early phase of this investment cycle was painful, but we believe the setup is improving and chose to maintain our position.

Notable 4Q and 2025 Contributors

Google parent Alphabet was the Fund’s top performer in both periods. The latest release of the Gemini AI surpassed expectations, with several benchmarks showing Gemini’s performance moved to the front of the pack. A pickup in growth among Danaher and Thermo Fisher helped spur a recovery in their shares. Thermo’s fourth quarter rally also pushed its shares onto the annual contributor list. IDEX and Amazon round out the quarter’s top performers.

Perimeter Solutions (PRM) capped a strong 2025 by signing a new, extended contract for its firefighting solutions and services with the U.S. Forest Service. Berkshire Hathaway was another top 2025 contributor, reflecting both its “port in the storm” characteristics during periods of heightened volatility and another year of solid operating performance. As legendary CEO Warren Buffett steps aside and Greg Abel assumes the CEO role, we remain confident that Berkshire’s reputation and prospects are firmly intact. Shares of Microsoft and Thermo round out the top 5 annual contributors.

Notable 4Q and 2025 Detractors

Liberty Broadband (LBRDK) is a standout detractor in both periods. As discussed above in more detail, we look forward to an improved cash flow posture in 2026. SiriusXM shares stalled as we await a more robust auto market and the end of the current satellite investment cycle. Euronet Worldwide completed its acquisition of Corecard, while Microsoft and Roper round out the top quarterly detractors.

As detailed above, CarMax was the Fund’s top full-year detractor and was sold. Shares of Global Payments have yet to recover from the aggressive sell-off after announcing their intention to acquire Worldpay. The deal closed in early 2026, and we look forward to more operating details from the company and the planned reduction in debt. Finally, despite positive returns in the fourth quarter, IDEX and Bio-Techne round out the full-year detractors list.

4Q Portfolio Changes

Beyond selling CarMax this quarter, other portfolio changes include closing our positions in Labcorp and Perimeter Solutions, as both traded around our base-case valuations. We also exited our small position in GCI Liberty (received via spin-off from Liberty Broadband) at a small profit. We received shares of Euronet in its acquisition of Corecard but otherwise did not add any new companies to the portfolio. Trims of Alphabet, Danaher, Thermo Fisher, Microsoft and Global Payments (GPN) were partially offset by additions to Aon and Roper Technologies. The Fund did not maintain any short positions during the fourth quarter, exiting the year with a net long position of 93% of Fund assets.

All data is as of 12/31/2025 unless otherwise indicated.

The opinions expressed are those of Weitz Investment Management and are not meant as investment advice or to predict or project the future performance of any investment product. The opinions are current through 1/12/2026, are subject to change at any time based on market and other current conditions, and no forecasts can be guaranteed. This commentary is being provided as a general source of information and is not intended as a recommendation to purchase, sell, or hold any specific security or to engage in any investment strategy. Investment decisions should always be made based on an investor's specific objectives, financial needs, risk tolerance and time horizon.

Data quoted is past performance and current performance may be lower or higher. Past performance is no guarantee of future results. Investment return and principal value of an investment will fluctuate, and shares, when redeemed, may be worth more or less than their original cost. Please visit weitzinvestments.com for the most recent month-end performance.

Investment results reflect applicable fees and expenses and assume all distributions are reinvested but do not reflect the deduction of taxes an investor would pay on distributions or share redemptions. Net and Gross Expense Ratios are as of the Fund's most recent prospectus.

The Gross Expense Ratio reflects the total annual operating expenses of the fund before any fee waivers or reimbursements. The Net Expense Ratio reflects the total annual operating expenses of the Fund after taking into account any such fee waiver and/or expense reimbursement. The Net Expense Ratio represents what investors are ultimately charged to be invested in a mutual fund.

On 12/30/2005, Partners III Opportunity Fund succeeded to substantially all of the assets of Weitz Partners III Limited Partnership. The investment objectives, policies and restrictions of the Fund is materially equivalent to those of the Partnership, and the Partnership was managed at all times with full investment authority by the Investment Adviser. The performance information includes performance for the Partnership. The Partnership was not registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940 and, therefore, were not subject to certain investment or other restrictions or requirements imposed by the 1940 Act or the Internal Revenue Code. If the Partnership had been registered under the 1940 Act, the Partnership's performance might have been adversely affected.

Performance quoted for Investor Class shares before their inception (08/01/2011) is derived from the historical performance of the Institutional Class shares and has not been adjusted for the expenses of the Investor Class shares, had they, returns would have been different.

Index performance is hypothetical and is shown for illustrative purposes only. You cannot invest directly in an index. The Russell 3000 measures the performance of the largest 3,000 U.S. companies representing approximately 98% of the investable U.S. equity market. Bloomberg U.S. 3000 Total Return Index is a float market-cap-weighted benchmark of the 3000 most highly capitalized US companies.

Effective July 31, 2025, the Fund selected the Bloomberg 3000 Index as its broad-based index for regulatory requirements. See the Fund’s Prospectus for additional information. Note that certain information, as noted herein, was measured against the Russell 3000, the Fund’s previous broad-based index.

Consider these risks before investing: All investments involve risks, including possible loss of principal. These risks include market risks, such as political, regulatory, economic, social and health risks (including the risks presented by the spread of infectious diseases). In addition, because the Fund may have a more concentrated portfolio than certain other mutual funds, the performance of each holding in the Fund has a greater impact upon the overall portfolio, which increases risk. See the Fund's prospectus for a further discussion of risks related to the Fund.

Investors should consider carefully the investment objectives, risks, and charges and expenses of a fund before investing. This and other important information is contained in the prospectus and summary prospectus, which may be obtained at weitzinvestments.com or from a financial advisor. Please read the prospectus carefully before investing.

Weitz Securities, Inc. is the distributor of the Weitz Funds.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

Editor's Note: This article covers one or more microcap stocks. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Rocket Lab: Impressive Results But Another Neutron Delay
data.description:
Thesis

Rocket Lab Corporation (RKLB) posted a pretty modest but very meaningful earnings beat for 4Q25 when you break it down. Reporting GAAP EPS came in at -$0.09, about $0.01 better than expectations, with a revenue figure of $180 million, beating estimates by $1.47 million. The results are showing me execution strength, especially in terms of scaling revenue while still containing losses. As for guidance, we can expect 1Q26 revenue to fall between $185 and $200 million. This was also above the consensus estimate of $180.9 million. Management also projected GAAP gross margins of 34% to 36%, but a narrower adjusted EBITDA loss of $21 to $27 million, which would imply much improved operating leverage with revenue bumping up. As for the investor sentiment, a lot of this stock's upside is seen to be dependent on the Neutron. So in that sense, we got two bits of new news that won't be taken too well by the market. First, the Neutron is getting pushed back until 4Q26, and secondly, there is the whole narrative around this tank rupture, which I will try to explain a bit later on. This is another Neutron pushback, but personally, I don't view the Neutron as the big growth driver here, but rather their space systems business. Historically, this is what is bringing in revenue for the company, and from the numbers we saw on the release, I'm still bullish at current levels.

Financials overview

I thought Rocket Lab delivered a pretty strong FY25, despite the stock closing about 4% lower yesterday. We saw some rapid top-line growth, an expanding backlog, and also strengthening operational scale. They’re even still continuing to invest quite heavily in future programs. FY25 revenue hit $602 million, up about 38% year-over-year from $436 million in 2024. Strong momentum across both product and service segments. Product revenue rose to $371.6 million, almost 28%, and was mainly driven by spacecraft/satellite components, whilst service revenue surged to $230.2 million, about 57%. We’re seeing increased demand for launch services and mission operations. As for 4Q25, it saw $180 million in revenue, a new company record, and also represented about 36% growth compared to the same time last year. This kind of revenue acceleration means Rocket Lab is no longer just a niche small-launch provider. The key driver here, and has been for a long time, their diversification across space systems, with defence contracts and science missions ramping up.

Profitability metrics are also showing meaningful structural improvement, but we are still seeing net losses. Gross profit for 2025 almost doubled to $207.2 million, compared to $116.1 million in 2024. As for gross margin, it expanded as manufacturing volume and operational efficiency improved. Non-GAAP gross margin hit 39.7%, up from 32.0% a year ago, with overall better cost absorption and improving unit economics, and that's in both launch and spacecraft production. However, what investors wouldn't have been too pleased with were the operating expenses, which rose to a hefty $436 million. Now, this was mainly due to a 55% increase in R&D spending, up to $270.7 million, which I think is just the aggressive investment in Neutron we should have expected. Selling, general, and administrative costs also increased, now up to $165.3 million, but are pretty consistent with scaling operations and integrating acquisitions. So as a result, the company reported an FY25 operating loss of about $228.8 million, only slightly worse than 2024’s $189.8 million loss despite us now seeing much higher revenue. It’s definitely improving operating leverage even with the spending staying elevated.

Now, below the operating line, Rocket Lab benefited from much stronger interest income and also some balance-sheet optimisation. Net interest income contributed nicely in 2025, with cash balances increasing substantially. This helped offset interest expense from prior debt issuance. But the company still recorded a net loss of $198.2 million, or about $0.37 per share. A figure only slightly higher than the prior year’s loss despite revenue rising by more than $165 million. Adjusted EBITDA also came in at a loss of $101.2 million compared to $96.9 million in 2024. Importantly, here it's the gap between revenue growth and loss growth that we want to see narrowed. That's where we will get future revenue increments, converting more efficiently into profit once some major development programs mature.

Total assets nearly doubled to $2.32 billion. We can put this down to higher cash balances, acquisitions, and also increased property, plant, and equipment. Cash and cash equivalents alone are now up to $828.7 million, compared with just $271 million a year earlier. We would expect this sum to increase since Rocket Lab needs significant liquidity to fund Neutron development and some other large defence contracts in place. Goodwill and intangible assets also expanded quite a bit due to some acquisitions like Optical Support Inc. and Precision Components Limited. Total liabilities are now down to about $602.6 million from $801.9 million, but I think we can put this down to convertible debt balances being reduced, whilst stockholders’ equity actually surged to $1.72 billion, up from just $382 million.

As for cash flow dynamics, we’re seeing some change in Rocket Lab, with operating activities using $165.5 million in cash in 2025, compared with just $48.9 million in 2024. It could be a reflection of higher working capital needs, especially inventory, but also of the heavier R&D spend. Investing activities consumed roughly $347.4 million; for the most part, this was for capital expenditures and acquisitions to support manufacturing capacity and advanced tech development. The outflows were also offset by $1.07 billion in financing inflows, which mainly came from some big equity offerings in 2025. These drove the year-end cash balance sharply higher.

Strategically speaking, one of the big areas we wanted growth in was the backlog. This expanded to $1.85 billion, up 73% year-over-year. This backlog is now anchored mainly by long-duration defence/government contracts. Keep in mind this also includes the $816 million Space Development Agency award, which investors are hoping will provide some higher revenue visibility into future years. Combine this 1Q26 revenue guidance of $185 to 200 million, which gives us about 57% year-on-year growth at the midpoint, the results would suggest Rocket Lab is entering a phase of accelerated scaling. We’re seeing revenue growth outpacing cost growth, and gross margins improving nicely. So in short, although they remain unprofitable, 2025 showed us a business moving from a development-heavy launch provider into a very diversified space systems prime contractor with much stronger margins.

Neutron delay is seen as an area of concern

One of the biggest concerns investors probably have is that it just seems like the Neutron timeline keeps getting pushed back with every earnings call. The first launch is pushed to 4Q26, which some may view as management telling us to, in reality, expect 1Q27 or later, since most have lost confidence in management's timeline expectations. But keep in mind that it can be very difficult for space programs to hit their first launch date after a major hardware failure. And a tank rupture isn’t good by any means.

Also on the call, there was a question about whether the Neutron would have been ready without the tank failure, to which management didn’t seem to give the most definitive answer. The result is a delay, and whilst I don't think it matters a lot for the trajectory of the company, it matters a lot for the stock. You see, if Neutron slips too far, investors may think it’s not going to come during their investment window. Many have bought into this stock purely on the anticipation that the Neutron would offer a boost, especially after shares fell back in the high $60 range.

There are also some massive opportunities for Rocket Lab, should they have an operating Neutron rocket. Some of these would include the Golden Dome launch needs. The Neutron is supposed to be Rocket Lab’s ticket into a new tier of missions. I also mentioned in my previous coverage the completely new TAM that would be unlocked should they have a higher-capacity rocket in the lineup.

Tank rupture

So a bit talking point was this tank rupture. I feel it’s quite early days to be writing off the launch or the stock based on this failure, but what made it worse was probably the lack of clarity. We will probably find out more later, but for now, I'm going to try to explain what we know. The failure happened on a first-stage Neutron propellant tank for the Neutron rocket during structural pressure testing. Now, keep in mind that this isn’t some random test article; this is actually one of the primary load-bearing tanks that holds cryogenic propellant.

So its job here is to basically carry the thrust loads from the engines and the mass of the upper stage. You see, a rocket's first stage has two main tanks, the fuel and the oxidiser. So each one has to survive both flight loads and also extra margin testing on the ground. Peter Beck told us on the call that the tank actually met its expected flight loads, but failed when they intentionally pushed it beyond that. So they’re trying to map out structural margins of the tank. So we can take it that it wasn't a design-level collapse under nominal conditions, but rather it failed when they were stress-testing the boundaries. If failures were to happen, I would want them to happen at this stage.

The key detail we wanted to know is why. The rupture seems to be traced back to a manufacturing defect at a critical joint, which I think is the tank closeout area. As far as I know, in a rocket's tank, that's the transition between the composite barrel and the dome section. Also, they told us that the joint was made by a third-party contractor using a hand-laid process and not Rocket Lab’s automated fibre placement (AFP) machine. They also used that contractor to move faster whilst the AFP line was being commissioned in parallel, so that makes sense on paper, but as a result, it’s clearly introduced risk. So the defect weakened that joint locally, and when they expanded the test envelope, it became the failure point. Importantly here, Rocket Lab said the rest of the tank behaved as expected, which would support their claim that this was just a process defect, and not an actual structural design flaw. The next tank is tipped to be already in production, and this time it’s being built fully in-house on the AFP machine.

So that said, this isn’t a trivial setback. Even if the new tank build is quick, it still has to go through the full qualification testing cycle. So that means pressure cycles, structural loads, and verification. And because this was a first-stage tank, it’s not just some minor subsystem; it’s the foundational hardware that gave investors so much concern. So if it fails again, the schedule resets again. But now we know it wasn’t a bad design and wasn’t random, and it still confirms that Neutron is deep in first-article manufacturing risk territory. So what I’m trying to say here is that whilst this was exactly the kind of failure you expect in a new rocket program, it also reinforces why 4Q26 feels a bit too optimistic.

Valuation

As for the valuation, Rocket Lab is essentially priced for near-flawless long-term execution rather than near-term fundamentals. However, we’ve known that for quite some time. The market cap sits around $37.5 billion, and the trailing twelve-month revenue is just over $600 million. The stock trades at a hefty 65x sales, compared to a sector median closer to 2x sales. It essentially makes Rocket Lab one of the most expensive industrial and aerospace stocks in the public market on a revenue multiple basis. Even if we take a forward view, the multiple barely improves, with a ratio just above 60x forward sales. So that tells me investors are discounting a lot of years of rapid growth and eventually some dominance in medium-lift launch and space systems. On balance sheet metrics, the stock trades at about 27x book value, versus a sector median of 3x. So it’s clear again that a lot of future success is already embedded in the share price.

The problem I see with this setup is that earnings-based valuation metrics are effectively unusable, there is no meaningful price-to-earnings ratio today, and even out-year estimates imply pretty extreme multiples. So it means that the equity story is resting almost entirely on revenue growth and strategic positioning here, not profitability. For me, that makes the stock very sensitive to execution risk, especially with investors betting so much on the Neutron’s schedule and cadence. If we see the Neutron ramp smoothly from here and also space systems' margins continuing to expand, then the valuation can eventually be justified. But if Neutron slips more materially in 2026, there is very little margin of safety in the current price. Rocket Lab is basically being valued like a future aerospace prime contractor today, even though it still looks financially more like a high-burn growth company.

Looking ahead

Looking ahead, here the story is going to be defined by two things: execution in space systems and credibility on Neutron. So in the near term, revenue growth should continue to be driven mainly by spacecraft manufacturing, defence contracts, and mission services. The good thing is that demand here already looks structurally strong. So I'm expecting the slow ramp-up in revenue here with the stock reacting positively to new contract wins in 2026. This is what gives the company a real business today, not just a future launch vehicle narrative.

However, we have to be realistic that the stock is still trading almost entirely on long-term expectations, which means slips in the Neutron schedule or ambiguity around hardware readiness will likely keep overshadowing revenue success. If Rocket Lab can show steady margin expansion in space systems and tangible, de-risking milestones for the Neutron throughout 2026, then I see more upside ahead at current levels. Also, that valuation can start to make more sense.
